Body:
In English, specificity of reference and the use of definite vs. indefinite articles don't always co-vary.

For example, in "A bird in the hand is worth two in the bush," and "The bird is the only living feathered creature," both "a bird" and "the bird" have non-specific reference.

However, in "A bird came to my window one day," and "The bird pecked at my cat's head," both "a bird" and "the bird" have specific reference.

But does the apparent independence of specificity and definiteness hold true across languages? (Does it even always hold true in English?)
Title: Does the relationship between definiteness and specificity vary across languages?

OwnerUser.AboutMe: I'm a conlanger who needs reliable information about real languages. By profession, I'm a speech/language therapist, so some of my questions may be work-related as well.
